channel.title: Visual Basic - Local File Access
channel.description: Im not sure what im trying to say but pretty much here is an explanation. My Programming 2 teacher will allow us to listen to music and play games in class if we make a program that can listen to music and play games. Well obviously the easiest way for me to go about doing this is using the Windows Media Player Active X Control and Shockwave Active X Control in VB Express 2008. Now for the Shockwave control I have save the .swf file and I need to link to this. So I have to put it somewhere in the project folder so when I take the program to school the program will still be able to access the file. Im not sure how to say what I mean but basically it is this. There is a movie file which has to have a file path. What I have now is C:/User/Matthew/My Documents/Visual Studio/Projects/Media Player/game.swf. Obviously when I go to another computer that will not work. What I need is something like /bin/game.swf so when I switch computers I will be able to access the file by putting it where the program is. If that doesn't make any sense tell me because I'm not really good at explaning things.

item.title: Visual Basic - Local File Access
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Either use relative paths or System.Windows.Forms.OpenFileDialog if you’re not a moron.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic - Local File Access
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

just use a relative path…

“./bin/game.swf”

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic - Local File Access
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

True I was thinking the same thing. Also, I just noticed I added this to the wrong section. I was instead thinking of making a folder in which I would put all my Flash Games. Then on program startup the program would look through the folder for SWF files and list them under menu. So when I clock Menu it would list SWF Games. Then I click one of the file names and it opens that game in a new window. (That might not make any sense ethier). I would have to show what I mean by making the program.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic - Local File Access
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Why don’t you make the filepath changeable so you don’t have to change the program every time you want to watch something new?

Read full topic
